Community Hub
Retention
This game is about a person who kept running through his life, never looking back at the past. He rarely slept, and even with 24 hours in a day, it was not enough for him. Once during a trip, he gets into trouble. Now he's lying on the cold ground, buried beneath his bicycle. Slides of various moments fly through his head.
User reviews: Mostly Negative (308 reviews) - 31% of the 308 user reviews for this game are positive.
Release Date: Jan 13, 2015

Awards


Retention received award from Bytten for "Strangest Experience of the year"

Retention was the clear choice; nothing else I have ever seen shares its simple yet unusual premise. Choose images from your protagonist's past to decide on the future. The choices you make will determine his fate. This must be one of very few games I've ever played that made me think about my life outside of the game itself. Simple, unusual and emotionally powerful - this is a game that deserves recognition.

Andrew Williams and Steve Blanch // Bytten

Reviews

“While Retention doesn't last long it is a worthwhile experience, and you'll need to play through three times to see all the photographs. I found it to be intriguing and engaging during my short time with it.”
Gamerscape

“Retention is the only game I have ever seen try to create an experience consisting only of photos, it does so remarkably well, and creates an interesting game out of it.”
IndieBase

“Retention is a stylish staging of hundreds of photos, turning the collection into a character building exercise somewhere between “Memento” and “Choose Your Own Adventure” titles. Can a man be truly defined by frozen moments of his history? Is identity really just a question of perspective?”
Indie Game Reviewer

Energy Balance - don't miss our new game!

READ MORE

About This Game

This game is about a person who kept running through his life, never looking back at the past. He rarely slept, and even with 24 hours in a day, it was not enough for him.
Once during a trip, he gets into trouble. Now he's lying on the cold ground, buried beneath his bicycle.
Slides of various moments fly through his head.
Will his memories return? Will he be able to stand up again?
You must help him.

Features:
- Opportunity to tell a man by his memories
- Unique game genre "Game-Photo album"
- User-friendly interface
- 8 different endings (4 good / 4 bad)
- Original soundtrack included
- STEAM Trading Cards support
READ MORE

System Requirements

    Minimum:
    • OS: Windows XP
    • DirectX: Version 9.0
    • Hard Drive: 200 MB available space

37 of 39 people (95%) found this review helpful
Rena
80 products in account
13 reviews
Not Recommended
2.9 hrs on record
Posted: July 24
Wow!Just wow.
After reading some negative comments,I purchased the game,thinking that all the negativity is too harsh for such an interesting idea.I really wanted to like the game and put a positive vote.
After playing the game and finishing it in less than 10 minutes with random clicking on meaningless photos,which had no connection,I feel that I have lost some part of my mind.

It would be interesting if it was some kind of psychological test,but the real test here is to see if you have the mentality and strength to finish the game.I haven't,so after a while I started clicking on photos without thinking and i got the lost your memory result,although it felt like lost your mind result.

The only reasons to purchase is the low price,the trading cards and to give support to new,different ideas.

Hyo
949 products in account
42 reviews
Not Recommended
0.9 hrs on record
Posted: August 31
Retention is a slide shot of images with captions.

Why are you looking at me like that? You don't believe me? In this game you literally pick a picture, then it shows you a caption and you repeat that about 8x times, you have 10.5 minutes until the game automatically ends (you can turn that off thought), after, you get a final picture and some text depending on what you picked previously.

Is it interesting? Well, the concept is new, but that's about it, it feels rushed, as in they did had something but didn't quite took an advantage of it.

Is this a game? It's hard to tell, according to my dictionary a game is an activity that one engages in for amusement. Looking pictures is an activity, do I find it amusing? I don't think so.

Technically speaking, it is well designed, except for the resolution support.

★★☆☆☆ | Disliked It

Vic=HKC=
1,346 products in account
103 reviews
Not Recommended
1.0 hrs on record
Posted: September 18
This game is strange. I didn't really understood what I needed to do. I've to remember my life but the problem is: where is the connection? I mean, I have to choose pictures but what?

There are several endings but I never reached one. If the game is to write the story of the man, it's not clearly stated that you can choose any picture without having to fear to have picked a bad one.

Otherwise, the pictures are good, the game is having an interesting concept, but as it's not clear enough, I can't really recommend the game. Sorry.
